news.title: Trash talk, a walkout and a disinvitation: The drama behind the scenes at Davos
news.text:

Even Trump took note of his rivalâ€™s presence in Davos. Trump acknowledged the California governor during his speech, after Newsom was spotted watching it while leaning against a wall.

â€œI know Gavin was here. I used to get along so great with Gavin when I was president,â€ Trump said, referring to his first term. â€œGavinâ€™s a good guy.â€

Trump was less diplomatic toward some of his other targets. He said Greenland â€“ which he repeatedly referred to as Iceland during the speech â€“ was a â€œpiece of iceâ€ and â€œcold and poorly locatedâ€.
news.summary: US President Donald Trump set a trash-talking tone with his rambling address at the World Economic Forum, but he wasnâ€™t the only American ruffling feathers in Switzerland.

news.title: FCC warns late-night and daytime talk shows about political equal-time exemptions
news.text:
â€œThe federal equal opportunities regulations operate to prevent broadcast television stations â€¦ from unfairly putting their thumbs on the scale for one political candidate or set of candidates over another,â€ the guidance states. 

The bona fide exemption allows TV stations to air certain news-related appearances of political candidates without legally having to provide equal time to their opponents. 

The guidance comes after a Media Research Center report found that late-night shows hosted 31 Democrats and no Republican elected officials in the last six months of 2025.

The FCC said it received concerns that late-night and daytime talk shows have been operating under the assumption that the interview portion of all entertainment programs falls under the exemption established in a 2006 decision.

In 2006, the FCCâ€™s Media Bureau issued a decision exempting the interview portion of The Tonight Show with Jay Leno from the equal opportunities statute because it determined it was â€œbona fideâ€ news.

However, the renewed guidance states that the 2006 decision does not apply to all late-night and daytime talk shows with a program similar to Lenoâ€™s, and that programs must request the exemption.

â€œThis is not the case,â€ the guidance said. â€œThese decisions are fact-specific, and the exemptions are limited to the program that was the subject of the request.â€

The equal time rule was last enforced after NBCâ€™s Saturday Night Live hosted, then-Democratic presidential candidate, Vice President Kamala Harris, but did not give then-Republican nominee, President Donald Trump, the same opportunity. 

FCC Chair Brendan Carr called NBC out, and the network then gave Trump equal airtime. 

The FCC has not received any exemption requests from late-night or daytime talk shows, according to the guidance. 

â€œIt is important that both broadcasters and legally qualified candidates understand the FCCâ€™s equal opportunities regulations and how they can result in broadcasters offering opposing legally qualified candidates comparable time and placement,â€ the FCC outlines in the guidance. 

The Center for American Rights, a nonprofit conservative law firm focused on media issues, filed a complaint against late-night host Jimmy Kimmel in September, arguing that he consistently hosted Democratic candidates to whom he gave significant financial support.

Daniel Suhr, president of the Center for American Rights, said the guidance strikes â€œright at the heart of left-wing bias.â€

â€œThis important action puts Hollywood hosts and network bigwigs on noticeâ€”they can no longer prop up Democratic candidates with free airtime while shutting out Republicans,â€ Suhr told the Washington Examiner.
news.summary: The Federal Communications Commission issued new guidance on Wednesday on the application of the political equal opportunities statute, warning that late-night and daytime talk shows are not all exempt when they host certain politicians.  Under Section 315 of the Communications Act of 1934, broadcasters are legally required to offer equal time to candidates from different […]
news.author: Sydney Topf

news.title: Rahm Emanuel walks tightrope on Kamala Harris team vetting Josh Shapiro over Israel ties
news.text:
â€œIf you donâ€™t ask, given the trips that Walz makes to China and Gov. Shapiroâ€™s background, youâ€™ll have not done your job of â€˜vetting,'â€ Emanuel said during The Monitor Breakfast hosted by the Christian Science Monitor at the St. Regis hotel in downtown Washington. â€œOn the other hand, itâ€™s kind of self-evident how you know you were a double agent.â€

HARRIS CAMPAIGN ASKED JOSH SHAPIRO IF HE WAS AN ISRAELI AGENT, NEW MEMOIR REVEALS

He continued: â€œSo the phrasing of the question was not artful, as told by Tim Walz and Gov. Shapiro. But you have to ask. I mean, I was asked many questions by our security team before I got the security clearance as President Obamaâ€™s chief of staff.â€

Shapiro revealed the questioning from Harrisâ€™s team in his forthcoming memoir, Where We Keep the Light. According to Shapiro, Dana Remus, a former White House counsel, asked him: â€œHave you ever communicated with an undercover agent of Israel?â€

â€œWas she kidding?â€ Shapiro wrote. â€œI told her how offensive the question was.â€

Walz was also reportedly questioned over the trips he took to China before he ran for office and whether he was an agent for the Chinese Communist Party. 

Harris ultimately chose Walz as her running mate over Shapiro, who is widely seen as a possible 2028 contender. But the anecdote brings to light the tensions the Democratic Party faces over support for Israel amid rising antisemitism.

â€œIâ€™m probably not right to answer this question, because I kind of understand â€˜vettingâ€™ and security background. If the question was, have you ever talked to a senior agent of [former Syrian President Bashar al-] Assad, in this case, how would you know?â€ Emanuel said. â€œBut I understand the impetus of a vetting question to understand any political or otherwise liabilities.â€

Emanuel added that anti-semitism has long persisted irrespective of party affiliation. â€œItâ€™s not like anti-semitism showed up two years ago. Anti-semitism has been around for a really long time,â€ he said.

Although Emanuel insists he has not decided on whether he will run for president in 2028, he told reporters he will travel to Michigan, an important battleground state, in the upcoming weeks.

He claimed he was impressed by what Michigan has done on the vocational level because education is â€œthe ticket to how we fix this country, piece by piece.â€ 

Seizing on the populist fervor that has swept both parties, Emanuel chastized the â€œeliteâ€ for not apologizing for being held accountable for several disastrous moments for the American people, a sign that he may be laying down the groundwork to run for the presidency in 2028.

â€œThe war in Iraq, the financial meltdown, Chinaâ€™s decision to change from competition to adversary, and COVID. The one common thing: the elite to the establishment walk out great, and everybody else gets left with the bag,â€ he said.
news.summary: Rahm Emanuel believes the vetting process of Gov. Josh Shapiro (D-PA), in which he was asked if he was a double agent for Israel by former Vice President Kamala Harrisâ€™s team, was both â€œtotally inappropriateâ€ and â€œtotally appropriate.â€ The former mayor of Chicago, who is himself Jewish, underwent extensive vetting as former President Barack Obamaâ€™s […]
news.author: Mabinty Quarshie

news.title: Immigration enforcement arrives in Maine as a court freezes restrictions on tactics in Minnesota
news.text:
MINNEAPOLIS (AP) â€” Maine became the latest target of the Trump administrationâ€™s immigration enforcement crackdown, while a federal appeals court on Wednesday suspended a decision that prohibited federal officers from using tear gas or pepper spray against peaceful protesters in Minnesota.

The 8th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals was persuaded to freeze a judgeâ€™s ruling that bars retaliation against the public in Minnesota, including detaining people who follow agents in cars, while the government pursues an appeal. Operation Metro Surge, an immigration enforcement operation in Minnesotaâ€™s Twin Cities, has been underway for weeks.

Attorney General Pam Bondi praised the appeals court on X, saying the Justice Department â€œwill protect federal law enforcement agents from criminals in the streets AND activist judges in the courtroom.â€

Minnesota is a major focus of immigration sweeps by agencies under the Department of Homeland Security. State and local officials who oppose the effort were served with federal grand jury subpoenas Tuesday for records that might suggest they were trying to stifle enforcement.

A political action committee founded by former Vice President Kamala Harris is urging donors to contribute to a defense fund in aid of Gov. Tim Walz, her 2024 running mate.

â€œThe Justice Department is going after Trumpâ€™s enemies,â€ Harrisâ€™ email said, referring to President Donald Trump.

Feds turn to Maine as next target

In Maine, the Department of Homeland Security named the enforcement operation Catch of the Day in an apparent play on the stateâ€™s seafood industry. Maine has relatively few residents who are in the United States illegally but has a notable presence of refugees in its largest cities, particularly from Africa.

Secretary of State Shenna Bellows, a Democrat, said she wonâ€™t grant a request for confidential license plates sought by Customs and Border Protection, a decision that reflects her disgust over â€œabuses of powerâ€ by immigration enforcers. Renee Good was fatally shot by an ICE officer in Minneapolis on Jan. 7.

â€œWe have not revoked existing plates but have paused issuance of new plates. We want to be assured that Maine plates will not be used for lawless purposes,â€ Bellows said.

A message seeking comment from CBP was not immediately returned.

Portland City Council member Pious Ali, a native of Ghana, said thereâ€™s much anxiety about ICEâ€™s presence in Maineâ€™s largest city.

â€œThere are immigrants who live here who work in our hospitals, they work in our schools, they work in our hotels, they are part of the economic engine of our community,â€ Ali said.

Conflicts emerge in shooting incident

Greg Bovino of U.S. Border Patrol, who has commanded the Trump administrationâ€™s big-city immigration crackdown, said more than 10,000 people in the U.S. illegally have been arrested in Minnesota in the past year, including 3,000 â€œof some of the most dangerous offendersâ€ in the last six weeks during Operation Metro Surge.

Bovino defended his â€œtroopsâ€ and said their actions are â€œlegal, ethical and moral.â€

Julia Decker, policy director at the Immigrant Law Center of Minnesota, said advocates have no way of knowing whether the governmentâ€™s arrest numbers and descriptions of the people in custody are accurate.

Separately, a federal judge said heâ€™s prepared to grant bond and release two men after hearing conflicting testimony about an alleged assault on an immigration officer. Prosecutors are appealing. One of the men was shot in the thigh by the officer during the encounter last week.

The officer said he was repeatedly struck with a broom and with snow shovels while trying to subdue and arrest Alfredo Alejandro Aljorna following a car crash and foot chase.

Aljorna and Julio Cesar Sosa-Celis denied assaulting the officer. Neither video evidence nor three eyewitnesses supported the officerâ€™s account about the broom and shovels or that there had been a third person involved.

Aljorna and Sosa-Celis do not have violent criminal records, their attorneys said, and both had been working as DoorDash drivers at night to avoid encounters with federal agents.

U.S. Magistrate Judge Douglas Micko said they still could be detained by ICE even if released from custody in the assault case.

news.author: Associated Press,Maria D'Agostino

news.title: Michelle Obama would â€˜actively work againstâ€™ a hypothetical third term from Barack, she says
news.text:
Former first lady Michelle Obama said Wednesday during an interview on the â€œCall Her Daddyâ€ podcast that she would actively work against her husband, former President Barack Obama, running for a hypothetical third term.

Asked by host Alex Cooper if Obama would consider running for a hypothetical third term, the former first lady said she hoped he wouldnâ€™t.

â€œI hope not,â€ the former first lady responded. â€œI would actively work against that.â€

â€œI would be at home working against it,â€ she added.

President Donald Trump has teased running for a third term and has said he probably wouldnâ€™t do it.

Obama told Cooper that she believed eight years in office was enough.

â€œI do believe in the need for new vision, right? I mean, the two terms is not just about, â€˜We like them, and we want it.â€™ Itâ€™s just like, weâ€™re changing and growing so fast. This is a hard job, and it requires new energy, new vision all the time, new ways of looking at the world, right? So, I do believe that eight years is enough,â€ Obama said.

Obama said there would be no room for younger leaders to step up if the same ones kept running for office.

â€œHow are we going to build young leaders if the same people keep doing it again and again and again? You know, now itâ€™s your turn. Now itâ€™s my turn. Then you did it again, and Iâ€™ll do it again. Itâ€™s like, and thereâ€™s all these young, smart people who are just looking outside with their ideas as leaders get older and older. 

â€œYou know, the older you get, the more you just live a different life as an older established person. And I think thereâ€™s room for that wisdom, but thereâ€™s room for new ideas to come in. So, I think two terms is enough, for everybody,â€ the former first lady continued.

Obama also warned Democrats against denying that sexism still plays a role in national elections during the interview on Wednesday. 

She pointed to former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton and former Vice President Kamala Harris as examples.

â€œWe would just be silly to think that there arenâ€™t just some gut kind of, I donâ€™t know, like, weâ€™re not even analyzing what those feelings are about because weâ€™re trying to pretend like itâ€™s all better,â€ Obama said.

The former first lady said at an event in November that the country wasnâ€™t ready for a female president, citing the results of the 2024 election.

â€œAs we saw in this past election, sadly, we ainâ€™t ready,â€ she said. â€œThatâ€™s why Iâ€™m like, donâ€™t even look at me about running, because you all are lying. Youâ€™re not ready for a woman. You are not.â€

The former first lady went on to say that she did not believe men in America are comfortable with a woman leading them.
news.summary: Former first lady tells 'Call Her Daddy' podcast that eight years in office is enough for any president.
news.author: Fox News

news.title: Michelle Obama Complains People Only Know Her For Being Married To Barack
news.text:
Former first lady Michelle Obama complained that people solely viewed her as â€œBarack Obamaâ€™s wifeâ€ during a Wednesday episode of â€œCall Her Daddy.â€

The former first lady graduated from both Princeton University and Harvard Law School and held multiple professional roles before entering the White House. She expressed frustration on the podcast about how being the former presidentâ€™s wife overshadowed her personal accomplishments. (RELATED: Kayleigh McEnany Derides Kamala Harris For Blaming Biden White House For Bad Reputation)

â€œ[P]eople would be like, â€˜Well, how do you know what to do in this role?â€™ And to me, it was clear that, oh my god, you donâ€™t know anything about what I did before I came here â€¦ But I was like, well, I went to Princeton and Harvard,â€ the former first lady said. â€œI mean, I practiced law. I was an assistant to the mayor in Chicago. I ran a nonprofit, a 501(c)(3) â€¦ I was a vice president for community relations at the University of Chicago Hospitals. I was a dean of students.â€

â€œ[A]ll of that just disappeared in the course of this whole election, and you now see me as just Barack Obamaâ€™s wife â€¦ That quickly my shoes become the most important thing about me â€¦ not unique to me, it can happen to the best of us,â€ she added. â€œSo, I shied away from fashion leading the conversation. But I knew I didnâ€™t completely control it. So, letâ€™s lean in. Letâ€™s lean in with what we do. Letâ€™s make sure that we have a plan and a strategy in place for how fashion, just like everything we did in the White House, would have meaning and impact.â€

She also argued during the podcast that mothers should maintain their careers because children fail to appreciate their sacrifices.

â€œLetâ€™s be more honest about the struggle â€¦ I am constantly telling young mothers itâ€™s coming. You donâ€™t have to get off your career track. And I donâ€™t even recommend it,â€ the former first lady said. â€œBecause kids grow up fast. And then theyâ€™re gone. Youâ€™ve sacrificed everything. And you know, when they leave, they leave. They close the door and act like you never sacrificed.â€

Moreover, the former first lady lamented the difficulties of being a woman in America during a July episode of â€œIMO with Michelle Obama & Craig Robinson.â€

â€œWomen, we have so many landmines, and barriers, and donâ€™ts, and limitations â€¦ I think itâ€™s important for all guys listening, especially men raising daughters, to realize that difference,â€ she said. â€œAnd inadvertently, as you are loving and raising these beautiful girls, there are so many rules that make us small.â€

news.title: This grotesque Republican trend has metastasized
news.text:
One supposes that itâ€™s not an especially unusual phenomenon for politicians who ascend to power to do everything they can to cling to it. Between the ability to shape public policy and the trappings that come with inhabiting high office, political power is almost always an addictive drug thatâ€™s hard to kick. That said, itâ€™s also one of the hallmarks and great strengths of American democracy that, for most of the last 250 years, politicians of all parties have accepted â€” usually honorably â€” the will of voters.

Tragically, however, this great tradition of honor and discipline was egregiously abandoned by Donald Trump in the aftermath of the 2020 election â€” an action that led directly to the infamous January 6, 2021, insurrection. And now, five years later, itâ€™s clear that this new practice of, when necessary, taking every conceivable step to evade the will of the citizenry in order to cling to power, has become the new modus operandi of Trumpâ€™s party in North Carolina.

We, of course, should have seen this coming. That the fear of voter decisions and the willingness to subvert them had become a new Republican tactic of choice was first made blatantly obvious in 2013 when the GOP-dominated General Assembly began enacting election law changes (like the infamous Monster Voting Law) that went to extreme lengths to both suppress the vote of disfavored groups â€” most notably voters of color â€” and rig electoral outcomes through the use of extreme partisan gerrymandering.

The practice continued in the weeks immediately following the 2016 election. That was the period during which the lame duck GOP-dominated General Assembly hastily convened to enact laws stripping the newly elected Democratic governor, Roy Cooper, of an array of basic powers long and logically attached to the office.

Never mind that voters chose Cooper with the eminently reasonable expectation that he would wield authority â€” like numerous important appointment powers â€” long and naturally associated with the role of a stateâ€™s chief executive. Ignoring the obvious will of voters, GOP legislators moved quickly to remove them, and in most instances, seize them for themselves.

And in recent years, sadly, this trend has only continued to metastasize and become even more ingrained.

See, for example, the ongoing effort to take gerrymandering to ever greater depths by, quite literally, rendering the results of almost all legislative elections foreordained and rigged to elect large Republican majorities. Late last year, the GOP took this practice to a new and truly preposterous level when, heeding the dictates of Dear Leader Trump, it further rigged the stateâ€™s congressional elections so that our deeply purple state will almost assuredly be represented by a U.S. House delegation of 11 Republicans and three Democrats.

And then of course, there was the almost laughably bizarre move to, in the aftermath of Democrat Josh Steinâ€™s landslide victory in the 2024 election, seize even more gubernatorial power â€” like appointing the state Board of Elections â€” and hand it to, of all people, the stateâ€™s accountant (i.e. the auditor). It was a move so blatant and utterly contemptuous of the will of voters that it left many observers to conclude that Republicans would have gladly handed the seized power over to whatever GOP office holder happened to be handy â€” the Labor Commissioner? Agriculture Commissioner? â€” if the new GOP auditor, Dave Boliek, hadnâ€™t been so cynically ready and willing to play along.

But wait, thereâ€™s more. As NC Newslineâ€™s Brandon Kingdollar reported on Jan. 19, the governorâ€™s office isnâ€™t the only one from which Republicans have shown themselves more than willing to seize powers in contravention of the votersâ€™ judgment. Newly elected Democratic Attorney General Jeff Jackson is also a target.

Despite ample evidence that Jackson has worked hard to approach the task in a nonpartisan manner guided by the letter of the law and the likelihood of demonstrable harm to our state, Republican legislators advanced legislation last year that would strip the AGâ€™s office of one of its central and most important constitutional duties â€” to challenge unlawful presidential executive orders that harm the state. 

One GOP lawmaker even promised he and his colleagues would wreak vengeance and render Jacksonâ€™s office â€œa feckless, empty shell of a position that has no authority to do anything,â€ if he dared to contest their action. Try to imagine that such a move could have occurred if Dan Bishop were AG and Kamala Harris in the White House.

All these moves come on top of many years of repeated legislative micro-aggressions toward Democrats elected to Council of State offices like the Superintendent of Public Instruction and Secretary of State via budget cuts and other power grabs.

Will this trend continue in the New Year? Itâ€™s hard to imagine that it wonâ€™t. While gerrymandering and political power jockeying has always been a feature of American politics, the modern, Trumpified Republican Party has taken both phenomena to new and extreme levels never seen before in American history. The only question that remains at this point is how much longer voters will stand for the fear and contempt directed their way by politicians supposedly sworn to serve them.

Senior contributor and award-winning journalist Rob Schofield authors regular commentaries and hosts the 'News & Views' weekly radio show/podcast. A part of NC Newsline since 2006, he served as editor from 2017 to 2025 and, prior to that, worked for many years as an attorney championing the rights of low-income people and civil liberties.
news.summary:
One supposes that itâ€™s not an especially unusual phenomenon for politicians who ascend to power to do everything they can to cling to it. Between the ability to shape public policy and the trappings that come with inhabiting high office, political power is almost always an addictive drug thatâ€™s hard to kick. That said, itâ€™s also one of the hallmarks and great strengths of American democracy that, for most of the last 250 years, politicians of all parties have accepted â€” usually honorably â€” the will of voters.

Tragically, however, this great tradition of honor and discipline was egregiously abandoned by Donald Trump in the aftermath of the 2020 election â€” an action that led directly to the infamous January 6, 2021, insurrection. And now, five years later, itâ€™s clear that this new practice of, when necessary, taking every conceivable step to evade the will of the citizenry in order to cling to power, has become the new modus operandi of Trumpâ€™s party in North Carolina.

news.title: Trump says he has a top choice to replace Jerome Powell as Federal Reserve chair, but skips on a name
news.text:
Donald Trump said in Davos, Switzerland on Wednesday that he has likely narrowed down his pick to replace Jerome Powell, the chair of the Federal Reserve, to one person.

But he declined to say who that person was as he spoke to CNBCâ€™s Joe Kernen after his speech to the World Economic Forum, a rambling address where he attacked his domestic and international political foes while finally ruling out military action against a Nato ally in order to acquire the territory of Greenland.

Trump spoke to Kernen on Wednesday afternoon and attacked Powell repeatedly over his refusal to cut interest rates to a greater degree, as well as for supposedly getting spooked when GDP numbers have a sustained rally.

He told Kernen â€œIâ€™d say weâ€™re down to three but weâ€™re down to two, and I can probably can tell you weâ€™re down to maybe one, in my mind.â€

â€œ[Powell]â€™s too late, heâ€™s always too late, except when it come to politics for the other side,â€ Trump complained in the interview. â€œRight now, if you announce great numbers, the stock market goes down. Because they think â€˜Oh, theyâ€™re going to raise the [interest] rate. Theyâ€™re going to kill it.â€™â€

â€œWhich truly stops you from having any great runs, and we want to have a great run,â€ the president continued.

Trumpâ€™s sustained criticism of Powell and threats to fire the chair of the Federal Reserve have caused fears on Wall Street and Capitol Hill both in the past. Most recently, senators including members of Trumpâ€™s own party expressed alarm after the Department of Justice, which is on a run of prosecutions targeting the presidentâ€™s personal enemies, opened a criminal investigation into Powell.

During his interview on Wednesday the president alluded to some of that criticism: Namely, his charge that Powell voted to cut interest rates during the 2024 election to benefit then-President Joe Biden and his running mate-turned-replacement, Kamala Harris.

The case even triggered a rare warning from Senate Majority Leader John Thune, who advised the administration publicly: â€œI havenâ€™t seen the case or whatever the allegations or charges are, but Iâ€™d say they better be real and they better be serious.â€

Powellâ€™s investigation by the DOJ is likely to seriously complicate plans to replace him in May, when his term expires as chair. It could also encourage him to remain on as a governor, as which he is serving on a separate term thanks to the complicated leadership structure of the Fed. Typically, chairs of the Fed step down as governors when they retire from the top job, but itâ€™s not unheard of for one to stay on.

The end of Powellâ€™s term falls under the shadow of the greatest efforts by the White House to erode the Fedâ€™s independence in recent history, and Trumpâ€™s own talent search to find a replacement.

His plans to do so could be further delayed by the Powell investigation launched by the DOJ, as two Republican senators (Thom Tillis and Lisa Murkowski) have resolved to place a hold on nominations for Powellâ€™s replacement until the probe is concluded.

â€œIf there were any remaining doubt whether advisers within the Trump Administration are actively pushing to end the independence of the Federal Reserve, there should now be none,â€ Tillis wrote on X.

In July of last year, Trump said it was â€œhighly unlikelyâ€ that he would fire the Fed chair. But that only came after he reportedly polled Republican lawmakers on the question and even showed them a draft letter of a termination notice intended for Powell.

â€œNo, we're not planning on doing anything,â€ Trump said at the time. â€œSo he's doing a lousy job. But no, I'm not talking about that. We get, fortunately, we get to make a change in the next, what, eight months or so, and we'll pick somebody that's good.â€
news.summary: Trump has flirted with firing Jerome Powell for months and recently his DOJ opened a criminal investigation into the Fed chair
news.author: John Bowden

news.title: Michelle Obama Still Believes America Isn't Ready for a Female President â€” And Claims There Are Men Out There Who 'Won't Vote for a Woman'
news.text:
Michelle Obama has addressed her controversial comment in which she said the U.S. was not ready for a female president, RadarOnline.com can reveal.

The former first lady clarified in an interview on Wednesday, January 21, that she believed the country was progressing and moving toward the direction where one day a female could be voted into the White House.Michelle Clarifies Her Remarks About a Female PresidentMichelle, 62, broke down her past comment while chatting with Alex Cooper on the Call Her Daddy podcast. 

While promoting her 2025 book, The Look, Michelle quipped: "That's why Iâ€™m like, donâ€™t even look at me about running 'cause you all are lying. You're not ready for a woman."

During Wednesdayâ€™s interview, Michelle explained her comment was mostly based in "humor" and noted she does believe the U.S. could one day elect a female president."Look, we've come a long way, you know? And what my husband has said, and I agree with (is) change takes time. Context matters, right? 50 years ago, we were fighting for the Equal Rights bill," Michelle explained as she noted "there are people alive today that couldn't marry the opposite race, couldn't love who you love. This is recent history of a country that's been around for hundreds and hundreds of years."

Michelle reiterated "it takes time" while noting the country is "moving in that direction" on electing a female president. 

When asked her thoughts on the possibility of a female being elected president, Michelle suggested there needs to be a larger conversation about why voters feel reluctant about a woman leading the nation. 

"There are men out there that were not gonna vote for a woman. You know, that â€¦ people have had those conversations, right," she said. "Let's just be real about it, and let's put that on the table and talk about what that's about.""Letâ€™s not be mad because I made the statement. Letâ€™s look at the fact that weâ€™ve had two really qualified female candidates," Michelle added in reference to past Democratic nominees former First Lady and Secretary of State Hillary Clinton and former Vice President Kamala Harris, who served in the Senate as well as Attorney General of California and District Attorney of San Francisco. 

Both Clinton and Harris lost to Donald Trump, who had no previous public service experience when he was tapped as the Republican nominee in 2016. 

Michelle also pointed to Clinton when she spoke about her husband Barack Obama defeating her as a "newcomer" in 2008."One who was first lady, secretary of state, well educated, you know. My husband beat her," the former first lady said. "People were more comfortable with him as a newcomer, right."

"We've had qualified women â€¦ There's a falling shortness that is happening that I, you know, Iâ€™d say, 'Look, well, why canâ€™t we talk about that. Why are we pretending that that didnâ€™t just happen," she added.
news.summary: The former first lady said she does believe the country is moving in a progressive direction where a female may be elected to the White House.
news.author: Haley Gunn

news.title: Gavin Newsomâ€™s Davos talk cancelled a last minute amid alleged State Department pressure: Report
news.text: California Governor Gavin Newsom was informed at the 11th hour that his scheduled talk at USA House in Davos had been canceled, according to Politico. The session, originally set for Wednesday (January 21), was organized by Fortune and was reportedly aimed at CEOs and other global business leaders.USA House, attending Davos for the first time as the US governmentâ€™s officially recognized headquarters, reportedly opted not to include any US officials in the discussion, Politico reported.In a private exchange obtained by Politico, a Newsom administration official accused the organizers of bowing to political pressure from the State Department. The organizer denied this, emphasizing that Newsom remained welcome at the venue.The incident reflects broader political tensions at the World Economic Forum, where Newsom, a Democratic governor and potential 2028 presidential contender, has sought to position California as an alternative to policies promoted by Trump officials in Switzerland, Politico noted.Denial of un-invitationIn messages cited by Politico, an event organizer clarified that Newsom had not been â€œun-invitedâ€ and that the decision was not influenced by any political imperatives.Bessent ridicules Newsom from Davos stageSpeaking from a Davos stage, US Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent took aim at the California governor, saying: â€œGavin Newsom may be the only Californian who knows less about economics than Kamala Harris,â€ Bessent said, drawing laughter from the audience.He also appeared to reference the scrapping of Newsomâ€™s Davos speech, questioning the governorâ€™s economic credentials.â€œI was told he was asked to give a speech on his signature policies but heâ€™s not speaking,â€ Bessent said. â€œBecause what have his economic policies brought? Outward migration from California, a gigantic budget deficit, the largest homeless population in America.â€
news.author: Ravi Hari

news.title: Bari Weiss â€˜expressed significant frustrationâ€™ with â€˜60 Minutesâ€™ correspondent during private briefings with reporters
news.text:
Weeks after abruptly pulling a 60 Minutes segment about Venezuelan migrants deported by the Trump administration to the notorious El Salvadorian prison CECOT, CBS News editor-in-chief Bari Weiss gave the greenlight for the newsmagazine to quietly air the â€œInside CECOTâ€ story this past Sunday.

Hours before the report finally ran, however, Weiss called several journalists to help shape coverage of the decision, according to Status News. It was during these private briefings â€“ conducted on background with the condition that reporters wouldnâ€™t directly attribute the information to Weiss â€“ that she took the opportunity to criticize Sharyn Alfonsi, the 60 Minutes correspondent behind the piece.

â€œStatus has learned that during these conversations with reporters, Weiss expressed significant frustration with Alfonsi, who had declined to make changes to her piece at Weissâ€™ behest,â€ Status Newsâ€™ Oliver Darcy reported.

The Independent has reached out to representatives for CBS News and Weiss for comment.

The broadside against Alfonsi in the background calls â€“ like Darcy, this reporter did not take part in these discussions and learned about them independently â€“ comes after Weiss has been on the receiving end of withering press coverage and internal criticism over her leadership of the Tiffany Networkâ€™s newsroom. 

The relentless scrutiny of her approach as editor-in-chief â€“ a position the anti-woke columnist was granted by Paramount chief David Ellison in October despite her dearth of experience in broadcast news â€“ reached a fever pitch last month when she dramatically pulled the â€œInside CECOTâ€ segment at the last minute, even though it had been cleared by the networkâ€™s legal team and promoted on CBS airwaves.

Amid widespread blowback both internally and externally, Weiss repeatedly defended her decision that the segment was â€œnot readyâ€ to air, citing the lack of on-the-record comments from the Trump administration defending their actions and legal justifications. Meanwhile, Alfonsi fumed in a memo to her 60 Minutes colleagues that Weiss's decision to spike the segment appeared to be politically motivated.

â€œOur story was screened five times and cleared by both CBS attorneys and Standards and Practices,â€ she wrote. â€œIt is factually correct. In my view, pulling it now â€“ after every rigorous internal check has been met is not an editorial decision, it is a political one.â€

Alfonsi also noted that if the White Houseâ€™s â€œrefusal to participate becomes a valid reason to spike a story, we have effectively handed them a â€˜kill switchâ€™ for any reporting they find inconvenient,â€ adding that the network goes â€œfrom an investigative powerhouse to a stenographer for the state.â€

The fiasco around the segment prompted network employees and insiders to suggest that Weiss could face a â€œrevoltâ€ from 60 Minutes staff, which was already suffering from plummeting morale following a yearâ€™s worth of controversies, such as Paramount paying Donald Trump $16 million to settle a â€œmeritlessâ€ lawsuit over the programâ€™s interview with rival Kamala Harris.

Meanwhile, with Weiss coming under additional fire over the â€œMAGA-codedâ€ reboot of CBS Evening News â€“ which has suffered a rocky rollout replete with internal discord, technical mishaps, cringey pro-Trump segments and soft ratings â€“ The Free Press founder has grown increasingly frustrated with the overwhelmingly negative media coverage sheâ€™s received.

Therefore, after finally giving the â€œInside CECOTâ€ story the green light to run this past Sunday â€“ with little promotion and up against the NFL playoffs â€“ Weiss rang up several journalists to offer her own perspective on the controversy and â€œdo her own PR,â€ as one Weiss associate explained to Status.

In general, this type of behind-the-scenes outreach by a network chief amid a media firestorm in which they are embroiled is unusual, as attempts at public relations spin are typically left to spokespeople and communications staff. Making it even more eyebrow-raising from Weiss, however, was what was said during those calls â€“ namely, the criticism of Alfonsi.

â€œWhile it is no secret that Weiss and Alfonsi are at odds, the fact that the networkâ€™s top editorial executive would voice irritation with one of her marquee correspondents to outside journalists is, to put it mildly, extraordinary. Sure, disputes with subordinates happen at virtually every organization,â€ Darcy pointed out. â€œBut strong leaders keep disagreements within the house. They donâ€™t complain to the press about themâ€”especially when the subordinate is barred from advocating in the press on her own behalf.â€

Indeed, with morale sinking at CBS News as a whole amid the networkâ€™s conservative shift under Ellison, who has been accused of trying to curry favor with Trump as he seeks regulatory approval in his hostile takeover bid for Warner Bros. Discovery, Weissâ€™ criticism of Alfonsi in her reporter briefings isnâ€™t going over well with staff.

â€œShe is so out of her depth itâ€™s astounding. Her inexperience is on full display,â€ one network reporter told The Independent. â€œHow long must we endure this fiasco?â€

Another 60 Minutes staffer told Status that Weiss was â€œdeflectingâ€ the widespread backlash she has faced since joining CBS by â€œblaming us,â€ adding that she should have expected some pushback from the showâ€™s staff due to their experience and accolades. 

â€œThey know exactly what theyâ€™re doing, and they do it exceptionally well. Thatâ€™s why the show has been No. 1 for as long as it has,â€ that staffer said.

â€œOf course, thereâ€™s going to be friction when Bari walks in acting like she owns the place. These are the people who built it,â€ the staffer continued. â€œYou donâ€™t gain and build trust when you insult us, come in and say weâ€™re biased, donâ€™t learn the place [and] how we work, the fact-checking and research involved.â€

Another network staffer, who spoke to The Independent on the condition of anonymity to speak freely, stated that it seemed pretty apparent who Weiss had spoken to over the weekend based on the stories that were published about the situation.

â€œClearly those lines in news reports about 'people who work with Bari say she admits she got involved too late in the 60 process and wasnâ€™t aware of the effect a late decision would have on the 60 process' is from her private briefings with reporters that Status refers to,â€ the staffer stated.

â€œTrying to show itâ€™s an honest mistake and Iâ€™m learning - f*** that - itâ€™s not a difficult thing to understand how your involvement can f*** things up,â€ they added. â€œFirstly, you donâ€™t need to have worked in TV to get that and secondly, it reveals her arrogance because she could have asked what the ramifications were or listened when people protested.â€

In the end, while she held the story for four weeks, Weiss ultimately allowed it to air largely intact. While the report itself remained unchanged from the previously submitted version, which briefly ran on a Canadian network before CBS News pulled it back, 60 Minutes added portions to the front and back of the segment. The bookended sections included additional comments from the Trump administration and details about an â€œoffensive tattooâ€ that one of the Venezuelan migrants interviewed by Alfonsi had removed.

At the same time, though, Weissâ€™ push to have a Trump official sit down for the story proved unsuccessful in the end. Despite her making it a top priority for the report to air, and the biggest reason she claimed it needed additional work to be ready to run, the Trump administration rebuffed 60 Minutesâ€™ efforts to score an interview.

In fact, as several outlets recently reported, Weiss reached out to the administration to get DHS chief Kristi Noem or border czar Tom Homan to speak with the program â€“ with Alfonsi making her way to Washington to conduct the interviews. 

â€œSince November, â€˜60 Minutesâ€™ has made several attempts to interview key Trump administration officials on camera about our story,â€ Alfonsi said during the aired segment on Sunday. â€œThey declined our requests.â€
news.summary: â€˜She is so out of her depth itâ€™s astounding. Her inexperience is on full display,â€™ one network reporter said of Bari Weiss. â€œHow long must we endure this fiasco?â€™
news.author: Justin Baragona

news.title: Davos: Bessent Mocks â€˜Kenâ€™ Doll Newsom and â€˜Sugar Daddyâ€™ Alex Soros
news.text:
U.S. Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent made his Davos debut today with a bang, ridiculing failed California Gov. Gavin Newsom and his connection to an infamous billionaire.

It would be difficult to be more radical than George Soros, the globalist billionaire who began his infamous career by collaborating with Nazis, but George's son Alex is doing his best to set a new record for sponsoring the worst leftist politicians. Among those, apparently, is Gavin Newsom, judging from a chummy photo of the two at the World Economic Forum (WEF) 2026 conference in Davos, Switzerland. Or, as Bessent put it, "Sparkle Beach Ken" Newsom was palling around with his "sugar daddy."

Scott Bessent just PUMMELED Gavin Newsom in Davos"He's here this week with his billionaire sugar daddy, Alex Soros!" ğŸ”¥"I think it's very, very ironic that Newsom â€” who strikes me as Patrick Bateman meets Sparkle Beach Ben â€” may be the only Californian who knowsâ€¦ pic.twitter.com/rdHEvghP2vâ€” Eric Daugherty (@EricLDaugh) January 21, 2026

Bessent grinned, "I think it's very, very ironic thatâ€¦ Gov. Newsom, who strikes me as Patrick Bateman meets Sparkle Beach Ken, maybe the only Californian who knows less about economics than Kamala Harris, [and] he's here this week with his billionaire sugar daddy, Alex Soros."

The treasury secretary eviscerated Newsom's record. "Davos is a perfect place for a man who, when everyone else is on lockdown, when he was having people arrested for going to church, he was having thousand-dollar-a-night meals at the French Laundry, and I'm sure the Californian people won't forget that. And I can tell my message to Gov. Newsom is: the Trump administration is coming to California. We are going to crackdown on waste, fraud, and abuse."

Bessent topped off his brutal takedown by stating, "I was told [Newsom] was asked to give a speech on his signature policies, but he's not speaking, because what have his economic policies brought? Outward migration from California, a gigantic budget deficit, the largest homeless population in America, and the poor folks in the Palisades who had their homes burned down â€” he is here, hobnobbing with the global elite while his California citizens are still homeless, shame on him. He is too smug, too self-absorbed, and too economically illiterate to know anything."

Alex Soros showing off his newest purchase from the World Economic Forum pic.twitter.com/Zn4S1GmxL0â€” Kevin Dalton (@TheKevinDalton) January 20, 2026

At the end, Bessent seemed to realize he'd gob-smacked listeners, because he joked, "Let me know if you need any further clarification."

For Our VIPs: Trump Argued at Davos That Europe Is Unrecognizable. The Numbers Don't Lie.

Newsom has enriched himself and increased his own power, so from his perspective, he's a success. From the perspective of any sane person, either living in California or viewing the crisis that state is in now, Newsom is a catastrophic failure. From his aggressive COVID-19 lockdowns to his irresponsible expenditure of taxpayer money to his LGBTQ fanaticism to his freebies for illegal aliens, Newsom has sabotaged California over and over. 

He banned schools from informing parents about child "gender transitions," he refuses to hand murderous illegal aliens over to ICE, and he has built up an $18 billion budget deficit. Residents of California have left in droves since Newsom took over, including multiple billionaires currently packing up currently over a proposed wealth tax.

Gov. Newsom is all hair gel and no integrity.

news.title: Fresh Humiliation for Gavin Newsom As Heâ€™s Barred From USA House Pavilion in Davos
news.text:
Wednesday hasn't been a great day for Gavin Newsom, California governor and one of the leading Democrat contenders for 2028. He's been in Davos for the last few days, buddying up to Alex Soros and hoping to reach into the deep pockets of the world's global elite to prop up his chances of winning the White House.

He was having so much fun being the belle of the Davos ball; the parties, the media attention â€“ oh, it was swell. That is, until Team Trump came to town. The fun, indeed, seemed to come to a screeching halt for Newsom once President Trump and members of his Cabinet descended upon the snowy ski town in Switzerland. 

It all started when Newsom was asked if he had any advice for those in the international community who had concerns over Trump's plans for Greenland. This led to a non-response from Newsom, who, while channeling his inner Kamala Harris, went on an extended ramble about backbones, Nobel prizes, and T-Rexes. Oh, and he also called U.S. Secretary of the Treasury Scott Bessent "smug."

READ MORE: Watch: Bessent Eviscerates Newsom in Savage Davos Take-Down â€“ 'Patrick Bateman Meets Sparkle Beach Ken'

Bessent, when taking to the stage at Davos on Wednesday, quickly reduced Newsom to a quivering mass of jello with an absolutely withering line of fire. Here's bit of what Bessent said, from our earlier reporting:

I think it's very, very ironic that Governor Newsom, who strikes me as Patrick Bateman meets Sparkle Beach Ken, may be the only Californian who knows less about economics than Kamala Harris. He's here this week with his billionaire sugar daddy, Alex Soros, and Davos is a perfect place for a man who â€“ when everyone else is on lockdown, when he was having people arrested for going to church, he was having thousand-dollar-a-night meals at the French Laundry â€“ and I'm sure the California people won't forget that.And, my message to Governor Newsom is the Trump administration is coming to California. We are going to crack down on waste, fraud, and abuse. 

Yowza, that definitely left a mark.

During his remarks, Bessent noted that Newsom was supposed to give a speech at Davos, but wasn't going forward with that plan because Newsom is "too economically illiterate to know anything." More Bessent:

And I was told he was asked to give a speech on his signature policies, but he's not speaking because what have his economic policies brought? Outward migration from California. A gigantic budget deficit. The largest homeless population in America. And the poor folks in the Palisades who had their homes burned down. He is here hobnobbing with the global elite while his California citizens are still homeless.Shame on him. He is too smug, too self absorbed, and too economically illiterate to know anything.

Fresh from that humiliation, Newsom found out that not only wasn't he speaking at Davos, he was barred from entering the USA House pavilion. The pavilion was set up to "celebrate the 250th anniversary of America in Davos in 2026, building on more than a decade of experience that Stromback Global brings to hosting independent gatherings in Davos and other global convenings."

Newsom wasn't best pleased at the freeze out, claiming USA House sponsor Fortune had bowed to pressure from the Trump administration.

As of this writing, the Trump White House had not commented on the USA House development. We're left to wonder what other humiliations await Gavin Newsom in Davos has he avoids his duties in California.

news.title: Court lifts restrictions on immigration officersâ€™ tactics in Minnesota
news.text:
An appeals court on Wednesday suspended a decision that restricts immigration officersâ€™ aggressive tactics in Minnesota, while Maine declined a request for more undercover license plates for U.S. Customs and Border Protection vehicles, citing â€œabuses of powerâ€ during the Trump administrationâ€™s crackdown.

The 8th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals was persuaded to freeze a judgeâ€™s ruling that bars officers from using tear gas and other steps against peaceful protesters while the administration pursues an appeal. Operation Metro Surge, an immigration enforcement operation in Minnesotaâ€™s Twin Cities, began in early December.

An injunction ordered last week by U.S. District Judge Kate Menendez harms â€œofficersâ€™ ability to protect themselves and the public in very dangerous circumstances,â€ lawyers for the government argued.

Minnesota remains a major focus of immigration sweeps by agencies under the Department of Homeland Security. State and local officials who oppose the effort were served with federal grand jury subpoenas Tuesday for records that might suggest they were trying to stifle enforcement.

A political action committee founded by former Vice President Kamala Harris is urging donors to come to the aid of Gov. Tim Walz, her 2024 running mate, and contribute to a defense fund.

â€œThe Justice Department is going after Trumpâ€™s enemies list,â€ Harrisâ€™ email said, referring to President Donald Trump.

In Maine, meanwhile, Secretary of State Shenna Bellows, a Democrat, said she wonâ€™t grant a request for confidential license plates sought by Customs and Border Protection, a decision that reflects her disgust over the tactics of immigration officers elsewhere. Renee Good was fatally shot by an immigration officer in Minneapolis on Jan. 7. A message seeking comment from CBP was not immediately returned.

â€œWe have not revoked existing plates but have paused issuance of new plates. We want to be assured that Maine plates will not be used for lawless purposes,â€ Bellows said.

Portland Public Schools, the largest and most diverse district in Maine, said it kept the doors locked at two schools for a few minutes Tuesday because of concerns about activity by Immigration and Customs Enforcement.

â€œThis is an understandably tense time in our community, as reports and rumors of immigration enforcement actions grow,â€ the district said.

Greg Bovino of U.S. Border Patrol, who has commanded the Trump administrationâ€™s big-city immigration crackdown, said more than 10,000 people in the U.S. illegally have been arrested in Minnesota in the past year, including 3,000 â€œof some of the most dangerous offendersâ€ in the last six weeks during Operation Metro Surge.

Bovino defended his â€œtroopsâ€ and said their actions are â€œlegal, ethical and moral.â€

Julia Decker, policy director at the Immigrant Law Center of Minnesota, said advocates have no way of knowing whether the governmentâ€™s arrest numbers and descriptions of the people in custody are accurate.

Separately, a federal judge said heâ€™s prepared to grant bond and release two men after hearing conflicting testimony about an alleged assault on an immigration officer. Prosecutors are appealing. One of the men was shot in the thigh last week.

Vice President JD Vance is expected to travel to Minneapolis on Thursday for a roundtable with local leaders and community members, according to sources familiar with his plans who spoke on condition on anonymity because the trip had not yet been officially announced.

Whittle reported from Portland, Maine. Associated Press reporters Ed White in Detroit and Ali Swenson in Washington contributed.
news.summary: An appeals court on Wednesday suspended a decision that restricts immigration officers' aggressive tactics in Minnesota.
news.author: Jack Brook,Patrick Whittle

news.title: Michelle Obama Suggests Hillary Clinton Only Lost To Her Husband Because Sheâ€™s Woman
news.text:
Former first lady Michelle Obama suggested on â€œCall Her Daddyâ€ Wednesday that Hillary Clinton lost to her husband Barack Obama in the 2008 Democratic presidential primaries because of her gender.

The former first lady said America was not â€œreadyâ€ for a female president on â€œIMO with Michelle Obama & Craig Robinsonâ€ on Nov. 14. She indicated on â€œCall Her Daddyâ€ that Democratic primary voters preferred her husband over the more experienced Clinton because he was a man. (RELATED: Kayleigh McEnany Derides Kamala Harris For Blaming Biden White House For Bad Reputation)

â€œThere are men out there that were not going to vote for a woman. People have had those conversations. Letâ€™s just be real about it. And letâ€™s put that on the table and talk about, well, whatâ€™s that about? Letâ€™s not be mad because I made the statement,â€ the former first lady said. â€œLetâ€™s look at the fact that weâ€™ve had two really qualified female candidates. One who was first lady, secretary of state, well educated â€¦ my husband beat her. People were more comfortable with him as a newcomer.â€

â€œAnd now we just had the former vice president [Kamala Harris]. Weâ€™ve had qualified women, and if theyâ€™re not perfect and they donâ€™t cross every T and dot every I, thereâ€™s a falling shortness that is happening â€¦ why canâ€™t we talk about that?â€ she asked. â€œWhy are we pretending that that didnâ€™t just happen?â€

Clinton and Obama were locked in a tight race during the 2008 Democratic primaries.

SiriusXM host Stephen A. Smith disputed Democratic South Carolina Rep. James Clyburnâ€™s claim that gender likely played a role in Harrisâ€™ 2024 election loss during a December episode of â€œStraight Shooter with Stephen A.â€ He noted that Clinton secured the popular vote by a significant margin against President Donald Trump in 2016.

Smith also expressed disagreement with the former first ladyâ€™s statement about America not being prepared for a woman to be president.

â€œI think weâ€™re very ready as a country to elect a woman, because I think women, by and large, are smarter, more composed, more disciplined than the men have proven to be,â€ Smith said.

news.title: FCC Says Talk Shows Must Adhere to Equal Opportunities Rule in Aftermath of Kimmel Scandal
news.text:
The Federal Communications Commission has issued new guidance on Wednesday warning that late night and daytime talk shows will not be exempt from the equal opportunities requirements put in place by Congress.

Under the Communications Act of 1934, Congress put protections in placeto ensure equal access to broadcast station facilities for legally qualified candidates for office, regardless of political affiliation. The rule covers individuals who have publicly announced their intention to run for office and qualify under applicable state or federal law to hold the office being sought.

In 2006, the FCC determined that â€œThe Tonight Show with Jay Lenoâ€ qualified for an exemption from the rule as a â€œbona fide news interviewâ€ â€” the first time that such an exemption had been applied to a late night talk show. 

â€œConcerns have been raised that the industry has taken the Media Bureauâ€™s 2006 staff-level decision to mean that the interview portion of all arguably similar entertainment programsâ€” whether late night or daytimeâ€”are exempted from the section 315 equal opportunities requirement under a bona fide news exemption,â€ the FCCâ€™s new guidance states. â€œThis is not the case. These decisions are fact specific and the exemptions are limited to the program that was the subject ofthe request.â€

The agency said it has â€œnot been presented with any evidence that the interview portion of any late night or daytime television talk show program on air presently would qualify for the bona fide news exemption.â€ It added that any program that is â€œmotivated by partisan purposesâ€ would not be entitled to an exemption under longstanding FCC precedent. 

The new guidance comes after ABCâ€™s â€œJimmy Kimmel Live!â€ was temporarily pulled from the airwaves back in September for remarks the late night host made following Charlie Kirkâ€™s death. 

At the time, FCC chairman Brendan Carr condemned Kimmelâ€™s remarks and urged local broadcasters to take action. 

â€œWhen we see stuff like this, look, we can do this the easy way or the hard way,â€ Carr said in a YouTube interview at the time. â€œThese companies can find ways to change conduct, on Kimmel, or thereâ€™s going to be additional work for the FCC ahead.â€

Following Carrâ€™s remarks, Kimmel would get pulled from ABC affiliate stations owned by Nexstar Media Group and Sinclair Broadcasting and the network would follow suit soon after. Kimmel was suspended for around a week before his show was ultimately restored. 

Carrâ€™s remarks would lead to criticism from both sides of the political aisle and he was ultimately pressed further about the Kimmel situation and pressures the Trump administration may be placing on the regulator during a Senate Commerce Committee hearing last month.

In addition to Kimmel, Carr has also previously threatened ABCâ€™s â€œThe Viewâ€ about pulling the showâ€™s bona fide news interview exemption. 

He also previously reiinstated a dismissed complaint against New Yorkâ€™s WNBC-TV, which accused the network of violating the FCCâ€™s equal time rule when former Vice President Kamala Harris appeared on â€œSaturday Night Liveâ€ during the weekend leading up to the 2024 presidential election.

â€œAny program or station that wishes to obtain formal assurance that the equal opportunities requirement does not apply (in whole or in part) is encouraged to promptly file a petition for declaratory ruling that satisfies the statutory requirements for a bona fide news exemption,â€ the FCCâ€™s guidance concludes. â€œIt is important that both broadcasters and legally qualified candidates understand the FCCâ€™s equal opportunities regulations and how they can result in broadcasters offering opposing legal qualified candidates comparable time and placement.â€

In a statement, the FCCâ€™s sole Democrat commissioner Anna Gomez said that â€œnothing has fundamentally changedâ€ with respect to the agencyâ€™s political broadcasting rules.

â€œThe FCC has not adopted any new regulation, interpretation, or Commission-level policy altering the long-standing news exemption or equal time framework,â€ Gomez said in a statement. â€œFor decades, the Commission has recognized that bona fide news interviews, late-night programs, and daytime news shows are entitled to editorial discretion based on newsworthiness, not political favoritism. That principle has not been repealed, revised, or voted on by the Commission. This announcement therefore does not change the law, but it does represent an escalation in this FCCâ€™s ongoing campaign to censor and control speech.â€

Gomez added that the First Amendment â€œdoes not yield to government intimidation.â€ 

â€œBroadcasters should not feel pressured to water down, sanitize, or avoid critical coverage out of fear of regulatory retaliation. Broadcast stations have a constitutional right to carry newsworthy content, even when that content is critical of those in power,â€ she continued. â€œThat does not change today, it will not change tomorrow, and it will not change simply because of this Administrationâ€™s desire to silence its critics.â€
news.summary:
The agency added that any program "motivated by partisan purposes" would not qualify for a bona fide news interview exemption


The post FCC Says Talk Shows Must Adhere to Equal Opportunities Rule in Aftermath of Kimmel Scandal appeared first on TheWrap.
news.author: Lucas Manfredi,Nexstar Media Group

news.title: US appeals court blocks lower court order limiting immigration agentsâ€™ use of force in Minnesota
news.text: A federal appeals court on Wednesday paused a lower court order that had restricted US immigration agents from using force against peaceful protesters in Minnesota, giving a temporary victory to the Trump administration as it escalates immigration enforcement in the state.The 8th US Circuit Court of Appeals froze an injunction issued last week by US District Judge Kate Menendez, who had barred federal agents from using tear gas and other crowd-control tactics against nonviolent demonstrators and legal observers while a lawsuit moves forward. Protesters in the Minneapolis area sued the administration in December, alleging their constitutional rights were violated during mass immigration operations.Government attorneys argued the restrictions impaired officersâ€™ ability to protect themselves and the public during dangerous situations. The appeals court agreed to suspend the ruling while the administration pursues its appeal.Minnesota has become a central focus of the administrationâ€™s immigration crackdown under â€œOperation Metro Surge,â€ a Department of Homeland Security initiative launched in early December targeting the Twin Cities. Federal officials say more than 10,000 people living in the US illegally have been arrested statewide over the past year, including about 3,000 individuals described as serious offenders in the past six weeks alone. Immigration advocates dispute those figures, saying there is little transparency surrounding arrests.Protests intensified following the January 7 killing of 37-year-old American woman Renee Nicole Good, who was fatally shot by an ICE agent during an enforcement operation in Minneapolis. Federal officials said the agent acted in self-defence, alleging Good attempted to run him over with her SUV. However, that account has been challenged by eyewitnesses, journalists, local officials and Democratic lawmakers, who cite video footage suggesting she was trying to drive away when the agent fired.A political action committee founded by former Vice President Kamala Harris has urged donors to support Minnesota Gov. Tim Walz, warning that the Justice Department is targeting political opponents of President Donald Trump.Elsewhere, Maine Secretary of State Shenna Bellows declined a request from US Customs and Border Protection for additional undercover license plates, citing concerns over â€œabuses of powerâ€ by immigration officers. Bellows said her office has paused issuing new plates until assurances are provided they will not be used unlawfully.Vice President JD Vance is expected to visit Minneapolis on Thursday for a roundtable with local leaders and community members, news agency AP reported citing sources familiar with the plans.
news.author: Toi World Desk

news.title: Court lifts restrictions on immigration officersâ€™ tactics in Minnesota
news.text:
MINNEAPOLIS â€” An appeals court on Wednesday suspended a decision that restricts immigration officersâ€™ aggressive tactics in Minnesota, while Maine declined a request for more undercover license plates for U.S. Customs and Border Protection vehicles, citing â€œabuses of powerâ€ during the Trump administrationâ€™s crackdown.

The 8th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals was persuaded to freeze a judgeâ€™s ruling that bars officers from using tear gas and other steps against peaceful protesters while the administration pursues an appeal. Operation Metro Surge, an immigration enforcement operation in Minnesotaâ€™s Twin Cities, began in early December.

An injunction ordered last week by U.S. District Judge Kate Menendez harms â€œofficersâ€™ ability to protect themselves and the public in very dangerous circumstances,â€ lawyers for the government argued.

Minnesota remains a major focus of immigration sweeps by agencies under the Department of Homeland Security. State and local officials who oppose the effort were served with federal grand jury subpoenas Tuesday for records that might suggest they were trying to stifle enforcement.

A political action committee founded by former vice-president Kamala Harris is urging donors to come to the aid of Gov. Tim Walz, her 2024 running mate, and contribute to a defense fund.

â€œThe Justice Department is going after Trumpâ€™s enemies list,â€ Harrisâ€™ email said, referring to U.S. President Donald Trump.

In Maine, meanwhile, Secretary of State Shenna Bellows, a Democrat, said she wonâ€™t grant a request for confidential license plates sought by Customs and Border Protection, a decision that reflects her disgust over the tactics of immigration officers elsewhere. Renee Good was fatally shot by an immigration officer in Minneapolis on Jan. 7. A message seeking comment from CBP was not immediately returned.

â€œWe have not revoked existing plates but have paused issuance of new plates. We want to be assured that Maine plates will not be used for lawless purposes,â€ Bellows said.

Portland Public Schools, the largest and most diverse district in Maine, said it kept the doors locked at two schools for a few minutes Tuesday because of concerns about activity by Immigration and Customs Enforcement.

â€œThis is an understandably tense time in our community, as reports and rumors of immigration enforcement actions grow,â€ the district said.

Greg Bovino of U.S. Border Patrol, who has commanded the Trump administrationâ€™s big-city immigration crackdown, said more than 10,000 people in the U.S. illegally have been arrested in Minnesota in the past year, including 3,000 â€œof some of the most dangerous offendersâ€ in the last six weeks during Operation Metro Surge.

Bovino defended his â€œtroopsâ€ and said their actions are â€œlegal, ethical and moral.â€

Julia Decker, policy director at the Immigrant Law Center of Minnesota, said advocates have no way of knowing whether the governmentâ€™s arrest numbers and descriptions of the people in custody are accurate. 

Separately, a federal judge said heâ€™s prepared to grant bond and release two men after hearing conflicting testimony about an alleged assault on an immigration officer. Prosecutors are appealing. One of the men was shot in the thigh last week.

U.S. Vice-President JD Vance is expected to travel to Minneapolis on Thursday for a roundtable with local leaders and community members, according to sources familiar with his plans who spoke on condition on anonymity because the trip had not yet been officially announced.

Jack Brook And Patrick Whittle, The Associated Press

Whittle reported from Portland, Maine. Associated Press reporters Ed White in Detroit and Ali Swenson in Washington contributed.
news.author: The Associated Press

news.title: Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent Roasts Gavin Newsom at WEF: â€˜Patrick Bateman Meets Sparkle Beach Kenâ€™
news.text:
Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent took aim at California Governor Gavin Newsom during a speech at the World Economic Forum this week, focusing on Newsomâ€™s economic record, his presence in Davos alongside Alex Soros, and his handling of issues such as homelessness, budget deficits, and pandemic-era policies.

Bessent remarked, â€œVery, very ironic that Governor Newsom, who strikes me as Patrick Bateman meets Sparkle Beach Ken, may be the only Californian who knows less about economics than Kamala Harris.â€ 

Bessent seized on Newsomâ€™s attendance at Davos with billionaire Alex Soros to highlight what he described as the governorâ€™s hypocrisy during the pandemic, stating, â€œHeâ€™s here this week with his billionaire sugar daddy, Alex Soros. And the Davos is a perfect place for a man who when everyone else was on lockdown, when he was having people arrested for going to church, he was having $1,000 a night meals at the French Laundry.â€

Newsom drew attention for criticizing world leaders for failing to stand up to President Donald Trump, saying, â€œItâ€™s time to buck up, itâ€™s time to get serious and stop being complicit. Itâ€™s time to stand tall and firm and have a backbone â€¦ I canâ€™t take this complicity, people rolling over. I should have brought a bunch of kneepads for all the world leaders.â€ His comments were praised by Soros, who posted on X: â€œGreat catching up with the real star of the 2026 World Economic Forum, my friend Gavin Newsom.â€

Bessent framed Newsomâ€™s presence in Davos as emblematic of misplaced priorities. â€œHe is here hobnobbing with the global elite while his California citizens are still homeless. Shame on him,â€ Bessent noted.

The Treasury Secretary linked Newsomâ€™s economic record to widespread dysfunction in California. â€œHe was asked to give a speech on his signature policies, but heâ€™s not speaking because one of his economic policies brought outward migration from California, a gigantic budget deficit, the largest homeless population in America, and the poor folks in the Palisades who had their homes burned down.â€

The Treasury Secretary presented the administrationâ€™s response to Governor Newsomâ€™s failed leadership. â€œI can tell my message to Governor Newsom is: â€˜The Trump administration is coming to California.â€™ We are going to crack down on waste, fraud and abuse,â€ Bessent said. His declaration echoed President Trumpâ€™s recent Truth Social announcement that â€œThe Fraud Investigation of California has begun.â€

Bessentâ€™s remarks come as the Trump administration intensifies its scrutiny of alleged fraud and mismanagement in several Democrat-led states. California is one of five states where $10 billion in federal childcare and family assistance funding has been frozen amid investigations into widespread fraud.

The Department of Justice has indicted Newsomâ€™s former chief of staff, Dana Williamson, on 23 counts related to conspiracy, fraud, and obstruction of justice. According to the Department of Government Efficiency, California was responsible for $305 million of a reported $382 million in fraudulent unemployment payments since 2020.

The federal crackdown includes the Department of Justiceâ€™s creation of a new division to enforce fraud laws nationwide, following a rollout detailed by Vice President JD Vance. While the divisionâ€™s initial focus is Minnesota, the administration has launched separate federal investigations into alleged fraud within Californiaâ€™s welfare, education, and unemployment programs.

In closing, Bessent questioned Newsomâ€™s fitness to govern: â€œHe is too smug, too self-absorbed, and too economically illiterate to know anything.â€
news.summary:
Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent took aim at California Governor Gavin Newsom during a speech at the World Economic Forum this week, focusing on Newsomâ€™s economic record, his presence in Davos alongside Alex Soros, and his handling of issues such as homelessness, budget deficits, and pandemic-era policies.

news.title: Trump shocks with proposal to make himself 'king of the world'
news.text:
The full text of a charter for President Donald Trump's proposed Board of Peace sounds suspiciously like plans to make himself "king of the world," according to a political theorist.

A charter was sent out with invitations to dozens of world leaders, asking them to join the U.S. president on a panel to oversee the postwar management of Gaza, but the full text, obtained by The Times of Israel, conspicuously does not mention Gaza.

"So, the 'Board of Peace' [sic] not only doesn't mention Gaza in particular; it proposes to make Donald Trump in particular (not the president of the United States) king of the world," said Jacob T. Levy, a political theory professor at McGill University.

Levy dug into the full text of the charter and analyzed its rules, which he believes sketch out a plan to make the 79-year-old former reality TV star the ruler of the global conglomerate and then pass that title down to one of his heirs.

"Membership is subject to a 3-year term limit unless the member state either pays a billion-dollar bribe or the Chairman â€” entirely unilaterally â€” decides to extend it," Levy wrote. "The Chairman may choose to *terminate* a member state's membership (even if it has paid!), which requires a 2/3 vote to override."

Decisions shall be made by a majority of the member states that are present and voting, but subject to the approval of the chairman, and Levy dismissed that arrangement as absurd.

"That's not how collective decision-making works," Levy wrote. "That's a curia regis or the medieval privy council."

Trump himself shall serve as inaugural chairman, according to the charter, and the chairman shall at all times designate his own successor.

"So Don Jr will still be in charge even if Kamala Harris wins the presidency in a landslide in 2028," Levy wrote.

"Indeed, at that point the membership of the United States is subject to the same whims of the Chairman," he added. Assuming the thing goes into force sometime soon, the US' initial three-year term will expire right about the time the next president is inaugurated... so Chairman Don Jr can either demand that President Harris pay the billion-dollar bribe or else terminate the US' membership entirely."

Levy argued that the arrangement was brazenly corrupt even by Trump's standards.

"Proposing this structure... is impeachable. It really is," he wrote. "Regardless of whether this organization ever even looks in the direction of Gaza, it's an assault on the international order subordinating the decisions of states to the personal jurisdiction of the Trump family."

"It's hard to be shocked anymore, I know, but we should be shocked," the professor added.
news.summary:
The full text of a charter for President Donald Trump's proposed Board of Peace sounds suspiciously like plans to make himself "king of the world," according to a political theorist.
